content.webTitle: Broadchurch recap: season two, episode seven – an uneven penultimate episode

fields.headline: Broadchurch recap: season two, episode seven – an uneven penultimate episode
fields.bodyText: Spoiler alert: this blog is for people watching Broadchurch 2. Don’t read on if you haven’t seen episode seven. Catch up with our episode six recap The Latimer trial Essentially, this was just set-up for next week’s finale – closing speeches from each barrister, a teasing moment when the jury came back into court to ask a couple of questions, a late-in-the-day suggestion that Ellie had bribed her sister to give a statement (which she kind of did). In the background, Mark and Beth’s relationship continued to freefall towards separation, destroyed by Mark’s affair, the grief of losing Danny, the lies and, indeed, the truth about Mark’s actions during those hot days of summer. (Also in the background: Tracey’s son was denied his right of appeal, and Jocelyn mourned her mother. An audience shrugged. The only really exciting bit was when Abby got what she deserved: “You’re a really horrible person” just about sums it up.) I’m not saying all of this part of the episode was filler, but I imagine we could have skipped straight to next week’s finale without it causing many problems. It’s hardly as if the legal arguments have been given at such a pace, or have been so complicated, that it has been difficult to keep up. Or if either of the closing speeches were particularly compelling television. Sandbrook Crikey. Maybe more of us should nip into hospital for pacemaker operations if the result is instant recovery and a new lease of life. We fairly ripped through the detail in the hunt for Pippa’s killer and Lisa’s whereabouts as Hardy commandeered Miller’s car (and her to drive it) and went clue-searching. So here’s what we – and Hardy and Miller – now know: • Claire turned up at court with the pendant following her furious parting with Lee and the advice of Paul to face her monsters. She says the pendant was hers, that she gave it to Pippa. But she also admits to stealing it after it was seized as evidence, resulting in the collapse of the police case. • Claire, Lee, Ricky and Kate’s stories about their whereabouts on the Saturday seem to make sense. (Although there is a lot of working going on for a Saturday, I must say.) • Gary Thorpe, who took over his dad’s agricultural services business was also Lisa’s stalker after falling for her hard when they went out. He borrowed some money from Ricky Gillespie. • Gillespie needed some prompting to remember Gary. Hardy and Miller now know Claire had his number in her mobile. • Ricky was hilarious when quizzed about a painting of bluebells he’s had for a year or two. “Errr, yes, they’re all right, you know. They’re a flower …” Meanwhile, Hardy has been increasing the pressure on Claire and Lee: on Claire by chucking her out of the cottage, causing her to rage madly in last week’s episode; on Lee by informing him that Claire was pregnant and didn’t tell her (but did tell him). Cue violent sea-fighting that started out quite scary and turned increasingly bonkers. It also gave Broadchurch another opportunity to use its favourite watery motif – only this time it wasn’t Alec being pulled beneath the waves, but the increasingly fighty couple. Lee is heading back to France, where nobody but one female person knows who he is. Presumably that person is Lisa, if Alec’s suspicions prove correct, and Lee only knows that Gary was Lisa’s stalker because he has a much stronger relationship with her than he’s admitting to. I wonder whether Lee and Claire are protecting Lisa, rather than each other, who possibly killed Pippa accidentally and asked for their help. Thoughts and observations • Beth is having a terrible time with Mark. But it is good to see her friendship with Ellie at least part-mended. Some respite for both of them. • Now that Hardy is miraculously fixed, he’ll soon be able to drive himself round. • I had presumed for ages that Maggie and Jocelyn were either still a couple, or at the very least had been lovers at some point in the past. The cliff-top picnic – which frankly looked more bracing than romantic – could have happened episodes ago. • I feared we were going to have some more grunty alfresco sex when Lee and Claire started rolling around in the water. Thankfully, we were spared that (and they were spared hypothermia). • “You know the boy who works at the local newspaper, Ellie Miller’s nephew? I might have shagged him.” “Bloody hell! I hope you gave him a good time.” • The judges advice to the jury was quite interesting – I don’t think I’ve ever heard that before. Obviously, I’m not sure how much to believe it. • The likelihood of an idyllic, freshly painted beach hut being spare and ready for Claire to break into and sleep in? Let’s just say there’s a waiting list of more than a year in my bit of Cornwall. • On which note: the likelihood of a British seaside town where it never rains? How long have we been in Broadchurch now? It’s not just an unseasonal dry spell any more …
